Body:
Several English demonyms (Englishman) are compound words ending in -man, but most are not (Greek).

The vast majority of -man demonyms refer to England and close neighbors: Frenchman, Irishman, Scotsman, Welshman, Dutchman, Norseman. Because of this, I thought the compound might be an early form that stopped being productive, but Dutchman and Chinaman are more recent â€“ and Greek dates to Old English Grecas.

Scotsman is unusual in that the non-compound form Scot is also acceptable. Chinaman is unusual in that it compounds China+man instead of Chinese+man.

Are there etymological rules or patterns behind these differences? Are there parallels in other languages?
Title: Why do only a few English demonyms have a -man suffix?
